title: 115_hr145
content:
The "Citizen Legislature Anti-Corruption Reform Act" or the "CLEAN Act" terminates further retirement benefits for members of Congress. The "CLEAN Act" terminates retirement benefits for Members of Congress under the Civil Service Retirement System, effective 90 days after enactment. No further contributions or deductions will be made for these Members. The "CLEAN Act" terminates retirement benefits for Members of Congress under the Civil Service Retirement System, effective 90 days after enactment. This does not affect any prior rights, entitlements, or benefits under this subchapter. Members remain eligible to participate in the Thrift Savings Plan as per applicable law. Regulations for implementation may be prescribed by the Director of the Office of Personnel Management or the Executive Director. The "CLEAN Act" terminates retirement benefits for Members of Congress under the Civil Service Retirement System, excluding the Vice President. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in title 5, United States Code. The "CLEAN Act" terminates retirement benefits for Members of Congress under the Civil Service Retirement System, excluding the Vice President. This includes the termination of further retirement coverage for Members of Congress under the Federal Employees Retirement System. The "CLEAN Act" terminates retirement benefits for Members of Congress under the Civil Service Retirement System, excluding the Vice President. For existing Members, no further Government contributions or deductions from basic pay will be made for deposit in the Treasury of the United States to the credit of the Fund. For new Members, they will not be subject to this chapter, and no Government contributions or deductions from basic pay will be made for deposit in the Treasury of the United States to the credit of the Fund. This does not affect any existing rights, entitlements, or benefits under this chapter for any Member. The "CLEAN Act" terminates retirement benefits for Members of Congress under the Civil Service Retirement System, excluding the Vice President. Existing Members will not receive further Government contributions or deductions from basic pay. New Members are not subject to this chapter. Regulations for this section may be prescribed by the Director of the Office of Personnel Management. The regulations under the "CLEAN Act" provide that Members with less than 5 years of civilian service will receive lump-sum credit as if they satisfied certain requirements. The term 'Member' excludes the Vice President. SEC. 3. PROHIBITING MULTIPLE SUBJECTS IN SINGLE BILL. Each bill submitted by Congress must focus on one subject clearly stated in the title. Effective for the One Hundred Fifteenth Congress and beyond.

SEC. 4. REQUIRING EQUAL APPLICATION OF LAWS TO MEMBERS OF CONGRESS. Members of Congress must abide by laws equally. SEC. 4. REQUIRING EQUAL APPLICATION OF LAWS TO MEMBERS OF CONGRESS. Any law that provides exceptions for Members of Congress or their staff will have no effect. This does not apply to laws allowing them to carry out official duties related to lawmaking. "Member of Congress" refers to Senators, Representatives, Delegates, or Resident Commissioners. SEC. 5. REQUIRING USE OF INDEPENDENT NONPARTISAN COMMISSIONS FOR REDISTRICTING. Each State must conduct Congressional redistricting in accordance with a nonpartisan independent redistricting commission. States cannot use federal funds for election administration unless they certify redistricting for State legislative districts is done by a nonpartisan independent commission. A nonpartisan independent redistricting commission must develop a redistricting plan. The commission must have an equal number of members affiliated with the two largest political parties in the state and none of its members can be elected public officials. The nonpartisan independent redistricting commission must have an equal number of members from the two largest political parties in the state, and none of its members can be elected public officials. SEC. 6. REQUIRING OPEN PRIMARIES. SEC. 6. REQUIRING OPEN PRIMARIES. Each State must hold open primaries for federal elections and certify open primaries for state and local elections to receive federal election administration funds. Open primaries allow any registered voter to participate in primary elections. The section defines the national nominating convention and primary elections held by political parties to nominate candidates for the office of President. The term "State" is defined as per the Help America Vote Act of 2002. The subsection applies to elections held after the enactment of the Act.
